title: Claudia Chan
text:
Hi, I am Claudia! I am a UCLA student pursuing a double major in Statistics & Data Science and Economics.
My professional journey is driven by a genuine passion for using data and code to bring clarity to complex challenges. From developing tools that modernize student learning to analyzing engagement patterns for mission-driven organizations, I specialize in turning raw information into strategic impact.
I thrive at the intersection of technical thinking and real-world strategy ‚Äî where thoughtful analysis guides decisions and creates meaningful results.

title: Contact Me
text: I am always open to discussing new opportunities, data science projects, or collaborative research. Feel free to reach out through any of the platforms below!

title: Portfolio
text:
Co-developer | UCLA Department of Statistics & Data Science

Objective: Modernizing statistics education by replacing static tables with interactive tools.
Impact: Used by 500+ students annually for distribution and hypothesis tests.
Features: Live reactive outputs at \(\alpha = 0.01, 0.05, 0.10\).
Tools: R (shinythemes, ggplot2), GitHub.

View Live App | GitHub Repository

title: Portfolio
text:
üìä Modeling & Machine Learning

Consumer Behavior & Household Size Prediction
Kaggle Regression Competition

Problem: Predicting customer household size‚Äîa key factor for targeted advertising‚Äîusing only initial sign-up data and Amazon purchasing history.
Approach: Developed a Random Forest model with extensive feature engineering, including keyword sentiment analysis for ‚Äúbulk‚Äù or ‚Äúfamily‚Äù items and gender-ratio logic based on purchase logs.
Features: Optimized model performance using Permutation Importance and residual analysis to minimize Root-Mean-Squared-Error (RMSE).
Tools: R (ranger,dplyr, tidyr, xgboost), Kaggle.

View on Kaggle


Monopoly Game Simulation

Problem: Determining long-term landing frequencies for properties involving non-random movement like Jail and Chance cards.
Approach: Built a Monte Carlo simulation engine using R6 classes to execute thousands of virtual turns and calculate exact landing distributions.
Tools: R (R6, ggplot2), Monte Carlo Methods, Github.
